00001 /// @source      Client.c
00002 /// @description Implementation of class Client.
00003 //  See licensing information in the file README.TXT.
00004 
00005 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00006 
00007 //  Application Description
00008 
00009 /** @mainpage A C-Language Library for Writing Generic TCP %Client Applications
00010 
00011     A library for writing simple TCP client applications, written in the
00012     C-language with an object oriented approach, using the Berkeley sockets
00013     interface, and intended to be cross-platform.  @par
00014 
00015     A <b> generic client </b> written with this library is a simple TCP client
00016     application created following a specific pattern that is built around three
00017     concepts: <b> state</b>, <b> event</b> and <b> command</b>. @par
00018 
00019     <b> State </b> is one of these     <br>
00020        (1) <b> CONNECTED_IDLE </b>     <br>
00021        (2) <b> NOT_CONNECTED </b>.     @par
00022 
00023     <b> Command </b> is one of these:  <br>
00024        (1) <b>CONNECT</b>              <br>
00025        (2) <b>SEND</b>                 <br>
00026        (3) <b>RECV</b>                 <br>
00027        (4) <b>CLOSE</b>.               @par
00028 
00029     <b>Event</b> is one of these:         <br>
00030        (1) <b>CONNECTION_CREATED</b>      <br>
00031        (2) <b>CONNECTION_DESTROYED</b>    <br>
00032        (3) <b>CONNECT_ERROR</b>           <br>
00033        (4) <b>RECV_COMPLETE</b>           <br>
00034        (5) <b>RECV_TIMEOUT</b>            <br>
00035        (6) <b>SEND_COMPLETE</b>.          @par
00036 
00037     There are also two other entities involved: an instance of the GenericClient
00038     class, provided by the library, and the <b>application code</b> written by
00039     the user of the library. The GenericClient class is informally derived from
00040     the Client class, which provides the basic methods for writing client
00041     applications. @par
00042 
00043     The general flow of control in an application written with this library is
00044     like this: <br>
00045        (1) the <b> application code </b> passes up a <b> command</b> to
00046            the GenericClient instance, <br>
00047        (2) which processes the received <b> command</b> and passes down an
00048            <b>event</b> to the <b> application code</b>; <br>
00049        (3) the <b> application code </b> then processes the <b> event </b>
00050            received from the GenericClient instance, and the cycle 
00051            repeats again. @par
00052 
00053     The GenericClient instance is driven by a state machine, which is described 
00054     below in pseudo-code:
00055 
00056     @code
00057 
00058     1. if state is NOT_CONNECTED
00059 
00060           // only accepts the CONNECT command
00061           do connect
00062 
00063           if result is OK
00064              set state to CONNECTED_IDLE
00065              return event CONNECTION_CREATED
00066           else
00067              // remains in the state NOT_CONNECTED
00068              return event CONNECT_ERROR
00069 
00070     2. if state is CONNECTED_IDLE
00071 
00072           2.1 if command is SEND
00073               do send
00074               if result is OK
00075                  // remains in the state CONNECTED_IDLE
00076                  return event SEND_COMPLETE
00077               else
00078                 set state to NOT_CONNECTED
00079                 return event CONNECTION_DESTROYED
00080 
00081           2.2 if command is RECV
00082               do recv
00083               if result is OK
00084                  // remains in the state CONNECTED_IDLE
00085                  return event RECV_COMPLETE
00086               else if occurred TIMEOUT
00087                  // remains in the state CONNECTED_IDLE
00088                  return event RECV_TIMEOUT
00089               else // error
00090                  set state to NOT_CONNECTED
00091                  return event CONNECTION_DESTROYED
00092 
00093           2.3 if command is CLOSE
00094               do close
00095               set state to NOT_CONNECTED
00096               return event CONNECTION_DESTROYED
00097     @endcode
00098 
00099     The <b> application code</b> doesn't have to be concerned with how the
00100     GenericClient instance works; its only concern is how to handle the events
00101     it receives from the GenericClient instance. @par
00102 
00103     The pseudo-code for the <b>application code</b> is open, but generally will
00104     be like the following:
00105 
00106     @verbatim
00107 
00108     1. if event is CONNECTION_CREATED
00109           prepare message to send to the server
00110           pass the command SEND to the library
00111 
00112     2. if event is SEND_COMPLETE
00113           update whatever controls needed by the application
00114           pass the command RECV to the library
00115 
00116     3. if event is RECV_COMPLETE
00117           process reply received from the server
00118           prepare another message to send to the server
00119           pass the command SEND to the library
00120 
00121     4. if event is RECV_TIMEOUT (*** optional ***)
00122           do whatever the application needs in case of timeout
00123           if business rules says try again
00124              prepare another message to send to the server
00125              pass the command SEND to the library
00126           else
00127              pass the command CLOSE to the library
00128 
00129     5. if event is CONNECTION_DESTROYED
00130           // can be the result of SEND, RECV or CLOSE commands
00131           // (most errors will automatically destroy the connection)
00132           do whatever cleanup the application needs
00133           pass the command CONNECT to the library
00134 
00135     6. if event is CONNECT_ERROR
00136           do whatever the application needs in this case
00137           if business rules says try again
00138              pass the command CONNECT to the library
00139           else
00140              end application
00141 
00142     @endverbatim
00143 
00144     Using the pattern described above, writing simple TCP client applications
00145     is a snap, because nowhere the TCP/IP networking code is seen. In practice,
00146     only the application code needs to be written. @par
00147 
00148     The goal here is not writing production-grade applications, but small
00149     utilities for testing scenarios, for prototyping new functionalities, for
00150     finding application bugs in servers, etc. In these cases, speed of
00151     development is of paramount importance, because often the programs created
00152     are discardable, throwaway utilities, with limited scope and functionality,
00153     which do no justify spending too much time in their development. @par
00154 
00155 
00156     The C code that implements the pseudo-code above is something like this:
00157     @code
00158 
00159     switch (genCli_waitEvent())
00160     {
00161        case CLI_EVT_CONNECTION_CREATED:
00162           prepareFirstMessage();
00163           genCli_send();
00164           break;
00165 
00166        case CLI_EVT_RECV_COMPLETE:
00167           processServerReply();
00168           prepareAnotherMessage();
00169           genCli_send();
00170           break;
00171 
00172        case CLI_EVT_SEND_COMPLETE:
00173           genCli_recv();
00174           break;
00175 
00176        case CLI_EVT_RECV_TIMEOUT:
00177           prepareAnotherMessage();
00178           genCli_send();
00179           break;
00180 
00181        case CLI_EVT_CONNECT_ERROR:
00182           printConnectionError();
00183           client_sleep(5);
00184           genCli_connect();
00185           break;
00186 
00187        case CLI_EVT_CONNECTION_DESTROYED:
00188           printOperationError();
00189           genCli_connect();
00190           break;
00191 
00192        default:
00193           printf("*invalid event %d\n", genCli_event());
00194           abort();
00195           break;
00196     } // switch
00197 
00198     @endcode
00199 
00200     Please refer to the <b>gen_client_1</b> example project for more details.
00201     @par
00202 
00203     The library also provides additional funcionality, presented by the Client
00204     class but in fact implemented by other classes (the Client class here acting
00205     as a façade). @par
00206 
00207     The most important of the additional functionality is related to the Message
00208     class. It provides an encapsulation for the buffers used when exchanging
00209     messages between client and server, and also provides the framing that
00210     delimits messages on the wire. Please see the documentation for the Message
00211     class, for the Client class, and the <b>gen_client_1</b> example that is
00212     shipped with this project. For the record, the more important methods
00213     provided by the Message class for the use of applications are
00214     (encapsulated by the Client class):
00215        @link Client::client_messageBuffer client_messageBuffer @endlink,
00216        @link Client::client_messageSize client_messageSize @endlink, and
00217        @link Client::client_setMessageSize client_setMessageSize @endlink.
00218        @par
00219 
00220     There is also a Log class, that is used internally by the library but
00221     can also be used by applications. Its main methods are (again,
00222     encapsulated by the Client class):
00223        @link Client::client_logInfo  client_logInfo @endlink,
00224        @link Client::client_logWarn  client_logWarn @endlink,
00225        @link Client::client_logDebug client_logDebug @endlink,
00226        @link Client::client_logTrace client_logTrace @endlink,
00227        @link Client::client_logError client_logError @endlink and
00228        @link Client::client_logFatal client_logFatal @endlink.
00229        @par
00230 
00231     There are some other classes used internally by the library, that may or
00232     may not be useful when writing the client applications: Mutex, Thread, Time
00233     and Timeout.
00234 
00235     This library is written to inter-operate with servers written using the
00236     library described in this
00237     <a href="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/IP/TCPServerFramework.aspx">
00238     article</a>. Specifically, the <b>gen_client_1</b> example shipped
00239     with this project works with the <b> server_2 </b> and <b> server_3 </b>
00240     examples shipped with the article above.
00241 
00242     To adapt the library to work with other servers it's very likely that the
00243     Message structure declared in the MessageImpl.h file will have to be 
00244     changed. Specifically, refer to the on-the-wire format of the messages
00245     exchanged between the client and the server.
00246 */
00247

00281 /// Client class.
00282 /// This class provides convenience members and methods to write simple client
00283 /// applications.
00284 /// @class Client
00285 
00286 /// Identification for the Log file
00287 /// @private @memberof Client
00288 static cchar sourceID[] = "ZCL";
00289 
00290 /// Global counter used when sending messages
00291 /// @private @memberof Client
00292 static uint orgSeqNo;
00293 
00294 /// Default server IP address in binary (127.1)
00295 /// @private @memberof Client
00296 static uint serverAddress = 0x7F000001;
00297 
00298 /// Default server IP address as string
00299 /// @private @memberof Client
00300 static char serverAddressStr[50] = "127.1";
00301 
00302 /// Default server TCP port
00303 /// @private @memberof Client
00304 static ushort servicePort = 4000;
00305 
00306 /// The client socket
00307 /// @private @memberof Client
00308 static int clientSocket;
00309 
00310 /// Default server reply timeout in seconds.
00311 /// (0 means immediate, -1 means infinite).
00312 /// @private @memberof Client
00313 static uint replyTimeout = TIMEOUT_WAIT_FOREVER;
00314 
00315 /// Default timeout in seconds when sending a message to the server.
00316 /// In principle the client doesn't need to mess with this, but it's here anyway
00317 /// @private @memberof Client
00318 static ushort sendTimeout = 5;
00319 
00320 /// State of the connection
00321 /// @private @memberof Client
00322 static bool isConnected;
00323 
00324 // ---------------
00325 
00326 // State of the client, valid only immediately after a socket operation
00327 
00328 /// Tells if the connection has been closed after an operation end in error.
00329 /// @private @memberof Client
00330 static bool connectionClosed;  
00331 
00332 /// Tells if there has been a format error on the wire right after a receive
00333 /// operation.
00334 /// @private @memberof Client
00335 static bool formatError;
00336 
00337 /// Contains the number of the error that occurred immediately after a socket
00338 /// operation.                                                                     
00339 /// @private @memberof Client
00340 static int lastSocketError;
00341 
00342 /// Contains the type of the error that occurred immediately after a socket
00343 /// operation. 
00344 /// @private @memberof Client
00345 static int lastErrorType;
00346 
00347 // private interface with GenericClient (sync if changed in either place)
00348 // see also client_errorType
00349 enum // for lastErrorType
00350 {
00351    ERRTYPE_CLOSED = 1  ,  // connection closed by server
00352    ERRTYPE_SOCKET      ,  // socket error
00353    ERRTYPE_FORMAT      ,  // invalid format on the wire
00354    ERRTYPE_SENDTIMEOUT ,  // timeout in send
00355 };
00356 
00357 /// Tells id there has been a timeout after a receive operations ends in
00358 /// error.
00359 /// @private @memberof Client
00360 static bool timeoutOccurred;
00361 
00362 // ---------------
00363 
00364 /// Tells if tracing is enabled.
00365 /// @private @memberof Client
00366 static bool isTracing;
00367 
00368 // ---------------
00369 
00370 // internal helper functions
00371 /// @cond hides_from_doxygen
00372 static int recvBuffer(int, char*, int, uint, bool);
00373 /// @endcond

00376 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00377 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00378 
00379 /** Closes the connection.
00380 
00381     @memberof Client
00382 */
00383 
00384 TC2API void client_closeConnection(void)
00385 {
00386    log_func(client_closeConnection);
00387    log_finfo("closing the connection with the server");
00388 
00389    socket_close(clientSocket);
00390    isConnected = false;
00391 }
00392 
00393 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00394 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00395 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00396 
00397 /** Tries to connect with the server.
00398 
00399     @memberof Client
00400 */
00401 
00402 TC2API bool client_connect(void)
00403 {
00404    log_func(client_connect);
00405    log_finfo("trying to connect with the server %s", serverAddressStr);
00406 
00407    isConnected = false;
00408 
00409    if (socket_connect(clientSocket, serverAddress, servicePort))
00410    {
00411       log_finfo("ok, connection successful");
00412       isConnected = true;
00413       return true;
00414    }
00415 
00416    lastSocketError = socket_error();
00417 
00418    log_ferror("error %d trying to connect with the server", lastSocketError);
00419    return false;
00420 }
00421

00431 
00432     @memberof Client

00551 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00552 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00553 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00554 
00555 /** Receives a message from the server.
00556 
00557     @param
00558     msg : address of a Message structure which will be used to store data
00559     received from the server
00560 
00561     @return
00562     true (reception successful) / false (reception failure)
00563 
00564     @memberof Client
00565 */
00566 
00567 TC2API bool client_recvMessage(Message* msg)
00568 {
00569    int ret;
00570    Timeout timeout;
00571    log_func(client_recvMessage);
00572    static cchar msgclose[] = "now closing connection";
00573 
00574    /// @cond hides_from_doxygen
00575    #define REM_TIME timeout_remaining(&timeout)
00576    /// @endcond
00577 
00578    assert(msg);
00579 
00580    timeout_init(&timeout, replyTimeout);
00581 
00582    // tries to receive the message's first part
00583    log_fdebug("trying to receive %d bytes (first part of message)",
00584       message_size1());
00585 
00586    ret = recvBuffer(clientSocket, message_start(msg), message_size1(),
00587       REM_TIME, true /*first part of message*/);
00588 
00589    if (ret != (int)message_size1())
00590    {
00591       log_ferror("error when receiving first part of message from server");
00592 
00593       // if timeout and not one byte has arrived then don't close connection
00594       if (timeoutOccurred && (lastErrorType != ERRTYPE_FORMAT))
00595          return false;
00596       goto ERROR_WITH_CLOSE;
00597    }
00598 
00599    // consistency check
00600    if (!message_isValidPrefix(msg))
00601    {
00602       log_ferror("invalid message prefix [%c] received from server",
00603          message_prefix(msg));
00604       goto FORMAT_ERROR_WITH_CLOSE;
00605    }
00606 
00607    // consistency check
00608    if (message_size(msg) > message_maxBodySize())
00609    {
00610       log_ferror("invalid message size [%d] received from server",
00611           message_size(msg));
00612       goto FORMAT_ERROR_WITH_CLOSE;
00613    }
00614 
00615    // tries to receive the message's second part
00616    log_fdebug("trying to receive %d bytes (second part of message)",
00617       message_size2(msg));
00618 
00619    ret = recvBuffer(clientSocket, message_start(msg)+message_size1(),
00620       message_size2(msg), REM_TIME, false /*not first part of message*/);
00621 
00622    if (ret != (int)message_size2(msg))
00623    {
00624       log_ferror("error when receiving seconf part of message from server");
00625       goto ERROR_WITH_CLOSE;
00626    }
00627 
00628    // consistency check
00629    if (!message_isValidSuffix(msg))
00630    {
00631       log_ferror("invalid message suffix [%c] received from server",
00632          message_suffix(msg));
00633       goto FORMAT_ERROR_WITH_CLOSE;
00634    }
00635 
00636    log_fdebug("received %d bytes from server, body:%d orgId:%d orgSeq:%d",
00637       message_size1()+message_size2(msg), message_size(msg),
00638       message_orgId(msg), message_orgSeqNo(msg));
00639 
00640    return true;
00641 
00642 FORMAT_ERROR_WITH_CLOSE:
00643    formatError = true;
00644    lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_FORMAT;
00645 ERROR_WITH_CLOSE:
00646    log_fwarn(msgclose);
00647    client_closeConnection();
00648    return false;
00649 }
00650 
00651 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00652 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00653 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00654 
00655 /** Tries to send a message to the server.
00656 
00657     @param
00658     msg : address of a Message structure with the data that will be sent to the
00659     server
00660 
00661     @return
00662     true (operation successful) / false (operation failed)
00663 
00664     @memberof Client
00665 */
00666 
00667 TC2API bool client_sendMessage(Message* msg)
00668 {
00669    int ret, size;
00670    log_func(client_sendMessage);
00671 
00672    assert(msg);
00673 
00674    // to make it easier to find this message in the server's log
00675    message_setOrgId(msg, thread_pid());
00676    message_setOrgSeqNo(msg, orgSeqNo++);
00677 
00678    size = message_size1() + message_size2(msg);
00679 
00680    // clears indicators
00681    lastSocketError = 0;
00682    lastErrorType = 0;
00683    timeoutOccurred = false;
00684 
00685    // tries to send the message
00686    log_fdebug("sending %d bytes to server, body:%d orgId:%d orgSeq:%d",
00687       size, message_size(msg), message_orgId(msg), message_orgSeqNo(msg));
00688 
00689    ret = socket_sendBuffer(clientSocket, message_start(msg), size, sendTimeout,
00690       isTracing);
00691 
00692    if (ret == size)
00693    {
00694       log_fdebug("ok, message sent successfully");
00695       return true; // ok
00696    }
00697 
00698    if (ret == E_SOCKET_TIMEOUT)
00699    {
00700       log_fwarn("timeout occurred when writing socket");
00701       timeoutOccurred = true;
00702       lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_SENDTIMEOUT;
00703    }
00704 
00705    else // if (ret == SOCKET_ERROR)
00706    {
00707       lastSocketError = socket_error();
00708       log_ferror("error %d when writing socket", lastSocketError);
00709       lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_SOCKET;
00710    }
00711 
00712    log_fwarn("now closing connection");
00713    client_closeConnection();
00714 
00715    return false;
00716 }
00717

00722 /** Configures how many seconds to wait for a reply from the server.
00723 
00724     @param [in]
00725     seconds : how many seconds to wait for a reply from the server.
00726 
00727     @memberof Client
00728 */
00729 
00730 TC2API void client_setReplyTimeout(ushort seconds)
00731 {
00732    log_func(client_setReplyTimeout);
00733    log_finfo("reply timeout: %d seconds", seconds);
00734 
00735    replyTimeout = seconds;
00736 }

00738 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00739 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00740 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00741 
00742 /** Configures the server IP address.
00743 
00744     @param
00745     ipAddress : IP address of the server
00746 
00747     @memberof Client
00748 */
00749 
00750 TC2API void client_setServerAddress(cchar* ipAddress)
00751 {
00752    log_func(client_setServerAddress);
00753    log_finfo("using server address: %s", ipAddress);
00754 
00755    strncpy(serverAddressStr, ipAddress, sizeof(serverAddressStr)-1);
00756    serverAddress = inet_addr(serverAddressStr);
00757 }
00758 
00759 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00760 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00761 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00762 
00763 /** Configures the server TCP port.
00764 
00765     @param
00766     port : service port on which the server is waiting.
00767 
00768     @memberof Client
00769 */
00770 
00771 TC2API void client_setServicePort(ushort port)
00772 {
00773    log_func(client_setServicePort);
00774    log_finfo("using port: %d", port);
00775 
00776    servicePort = port;
00777 }

00784 
00785     @param
00786     flag : true/false
00787 
00788     @memberof Client
00789 */
00790 
00791 TC2API void client_setTrace(bool flag)
00792 {
00793    isTracing = flag;
00794 }

00796 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00797 // PUBLIC INTERFACE
00798 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00799 
00800 /** Reports if there has been a timeout after a receive operations ends in
00801     error.
00802 
00803     @return
00804     true (timeout occurred) / false (timeout not occurred)
00805 
00806     @memberof Client
00807 */
00808 
00809 TC2API bool client_timeout(void)
00810 {
00811    return (timeoutOccurred && (lastErrorType == ERRTYPE_FORMAT));
00812 }
00813 
00814 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00815 // INTERNAL HELPER FUNCTIONS
00816 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00817 
00818 /** Receives a specific-length buffer from peer application, and checks for
00819     error.
00820 
00821     @return
00822     number of bytes received, or error
00823 
00824     @retval
00825     the number of bytes received, or error
00826 
00827     @retval
00828      0 : (SOCKET_CLOSED) connection was closed by the server.
00829 
00830     @retval
00831     -1 : (SOCKET_ERROR) an error occurred.
00832 
00833     @retval
00834     -2 : (SOCKET_TIMEOUT) not all bytes arrived within the specified time
00835     interval.
00836 
00837     @private @memberof Client
00838 */
00839 
00840 static int recvBuffer(int socket, char* buf, int len, unsigned nSeconds,
00841    bool firstPart)
00842 {
00843    int ret;
00844    log_func(recvBuffer);
00845 
00846    // clears indicators
00847    connectionClosed = false;
00848    formatError = false;
00849    lastSocketError = 0;
00850    lastErrorType = 0;
00851    timeoutOccurred = false;
00852 
00853    ret = socket_recvBuffer(socket, buf, len, nSeconds, isTracing);
00854 
00855    if (ret == len) // most likely result
00856       goto END;
00857 
00858    if (ret == E_SOCKET_CLOSED) // second most likely result
00859    {
00860       log_fwarn("connection closed when reading socket");
00861       connectionClosed = true;
00862       lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_CLOSED;
00863       goto END;
00864    }
00865 
00866    if (ret == E_SOCKET_TIMEOUT) // third most likely result
00867    {
00868       log_fwarn("timeout occurred when reading socket");
00869       // timeout not considered error if not one byte received,
00870       // only considered error if occurs int the middle of a message
00871       if (!firstPart || socket_partialLenReceived())
00872          lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_FORMAT;
00873       timeoutOccurred = true;
00874       goto END;
00875    }
00876 
00877    if (ret == E_SOCKET_ERROR) // fourth most likely result
00878    {
00879       lastSocketError = socket_error();
00880       log_ferror("error %d when reading socket", lastSocketError);
00881       lastErrorType = ERRTYPE_SOCKET;
00882       goto END;
00883    }
00884 
00885    // should not happen (!)
00886    abort();
00887 
00888 END:
00889    return ret;
00890 }
00891
